Introduction

What is Machine Learning?

Field of study that gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed.

Arthur Samuel 1959

Key elements:

  • A collection of examples
  • Algorithm to “learn”

Aim of Machine Learning

Train machines to explore useful features and learn data patterns to predict/infer a target event.

  • Supervised Learning

    Develop predictive model based on both features & labels

    • Classification - output a label of class
    • Regression - output a value in a continuous range

  • Unsupervised Learning (Clustering)

    • Group & interpret data based only on features

  • Reinforcement Learning

    • Learn a policy to execute actions in an environment

General Pipeline of Machine Learning

Data representation + Modelling + Evaluation + Optimisation

Pedro Domingos, 2012

Some basic questions

  • What could be the source of data?

    • Data can come from various sources like sensors, databases, web scraping, logs, APIs, surveys, or simulations.

  • How do we represent the data?

    • Data can be represented as structured formats like tabular data (rows and columns) or unstructured formats like text, images, and videos.
    • Features are categorized as categorical, binary, or continuous, often requiring encoding or normalization.

  • What is good data in the context of machine learning?

    • Good data is accurate, relevant, diverse, complete (minimal missing values), consistent, and representative of the target use case to ensure reliable model training and testing.

  • What makes a good feature?

    • A good feature is relevant, informative, discriminative, and repeatable, helping the model accurately predict outcomes while reducing noise and redundancy.

Gradient Descent Optimisation

Gradient descent is an iterative optimisation algorithm used to find a local minimum or maximum of a given function.

Aim: to find parameter w∗=[a∗,b∗]w^*=[a^*,b^*]w∗=[a∗,b∗] for a line that best fit these points (x,y)(x, y)(x,y)

  • a,ba, ba,b : parameter to be estimated

  • kkk : iteration

  • NNN : number of data samples

  • ααα: learning rate

  • loss function: f(a,b)=∑n=1N(yn−(axn+b))2f(a,b)=\sum\limits_{n=1}^N(y_n-(ax_n+b))^2f(a,b)=n=1∑N​(yn​−(axn​+b))2

  • Calculate partial derivatives:

    \begin{align*} \frac{\partial f}{\partial a^k} &= -2 \sum_{n=1}^N (y_n - a^k x_n - b^k) \cdot x_n \\ \frac{\partial f}{\partial b^k} &= -2 \sum_{n=1}^N (y_n - a^k x_n - b^k) \end{align*}

Probability- Random Variable

It is a variable X whose possible values are numerical outcomes of a random process.

It can be discrete or continues.

The probability distribution of a discrete random variable is a list of probabilities associated with each of its possible values (called probability mass function)

The probability distribution of a continuous random variable is described by a probability density function

    E[X]≔∫RxfX(x) dx\mathbb{E}[X] \coloneqq \int_{\mathbb{R}} x f_X(x) \, dxE[X]:=∫R​xfX​(x)dx

Bayes’ Rule

In many practical problems, the probability of one event occurs is often conditioned on another event.

Taking account of priors!

  • The conditional probability P(X=x∣Y=y)P(X=x|Y=y)P(X=x∣Y=y) is the probability of the random variable XXX to have a specific value xxx given that another random variable YYY has a specific value of yyy.

  • The Bayes’ Rule is: P(A∣B)=P(B∣A)⋅P(A)P(B)P(A|B)=\frac{P(B|A)\cdot P(A)}{P(B)}P(A∣B)=P(B)P(B∣A)⋅P(A)​

Note that the joint probability can be factorisedin two ways:

  • P(A,B)=P(A∣B)⋅P(B)=P(B∣A)⋅P(A)P(A,B)=P(A|B)\cdot P(B)=P(B|A)\cdot P(A)P(A,B)=P(A∣B)⋅P(B)=P(B∣A)⋅P(A)

If AAA and BBB are independent (do not affect each other), P(A,B)=P(A)⋅P(B)P(A,B)=P(A)\cdot P(B)P(A,B)=P(A)⋅P(B)

Frequentist vs Bayesian

Frequentist:

  • Long-term frequency of an event occurring.
  • Data driven.

Bayesian:

  • Assumes a prior model (knowledge) and update the model using data.
  • Model driven.

Data Pre-processing & Feature Analysis

  • Understand the data
    • Truly understand the underlying problem as much as possible.
    • Visualise the data (outliers, value range, etc.)
  • Feature representation
    • Reliability, repeatability
    • Categorical, binary, continuous.
    • Feature value normalisation
  • Data pre-processing
    • Missing data, errors, etc.
    • Data imputation

Data Normalisation

Methods:

  • Z-Normalisation (Zero-mean normalisation)

    • Xnorm=(X−μ)/σX_{norm}=(X-\mu)/\sigmaXnorm​=(X−μ)/σ
    • XXX is the feature vector of original values, μμμ and σσσ are the mean and standard deviation of vector XXX

  • Min-Max Normalisation

    • use 5%/95% percentile as the min and max more robust to outliers
    • Xnorm=X−min(X)max(X)−min(X)X_{norm}=\frac{X-min(X)}{max(X)-min(X)}Xnorm​=max(X)−min(X)X−min(X)​
    • Min(X)Min(X)Min(X) and Max(X)Max(X)Max(X) are the minimum and maximum values of vector XXX respectively

  • Vector Normalisation

    • Xnorm=X∣∣x∣∣X_{norm}=\frac{X}{||x||}Xnorm​=∣∣x∣∣X​
    • ∣∣X∣∣||X||∣∣X∣∣ is the vector length of XXX

Benefit of data normalisation

  • They are all linear scaling methods, so won’t affect the original data distribution
  • Improves the numerical stability of the machine learning model
    • e.g. using gradient descend to optimise neural network, if different features are in different value range a fixed learning rate will likely overshoot or undershoot the optima for certain features
  • Reduce the negative impact to distance-based algorithms
    • e.g. KNN, SVM

Data Imputation (deal with missing data)

Methods:

  • Use mean or median values
  • Use most frequent values
  • Use k-nearest neighbour based on feature similarity
  • Use multivariate imputation by chained equations
    • i.e. try filling the missing data multiple times with different values and pool the final results
  • Estimate the missing value using machine learning models based on other features.

Curse of Dimensionality

What is curse of dimensionality in machine learning?

Data samples are too sparse in the feature space.

i.e. the number of instances are not large enough to densely distributed in the feature space

What shall we do to avoid curse of dimensionality?

  • Increase the number of data samples.
    • The required sample numbers will need to increase exponentially with a linear increase of feature dimensions.
  • Reduce the number of features (more feasible)
    • use feature selection and dimensionality reduction methods

Feature Selection & Dimensionality Reduction

Aim of Feature Selection and Dimensionality Reduction

  • Reduce the impact caused by Curse of Dimensionality
  • Remove redundant features to improve performance
  • Increase computational efficiency
  • Reduce cost in new data acquisition

Feature Selection vs Dimensionality Reduction

  • FS retain a subset of the original features
  • DR generate a new set of features that is compact but does NOT retain the original meaning of features

Things to consider when using FS and DR

  • The target dimension
  • Interpretability (Yes: FS; No: Dr or FS)
  • Feature correlations/dependency
  • Feature reliability and repeatability
  • Methods (different methods likely to result in different features)

Popular FS Methods

  • Wrapper methods
    • Search for optimal feature subset that maximise the decision-making performance
    • Methods: recursive feature elimination; sequential feature selection.
  • Embedded methods
    • Integrate the FS process to the model learning process.
    • Methods: ridge (ElasticNet); lasso; random forest (feature ranking).
  • Filter-based methods
    • Selection is based on feature relationships and statistics rather than performance.
    • Methods: univariate (ANOVA); Chi Square; correlation/variance

Methods

Forward Feature Selection (Wrapper Method)

  • XXX: the final selected feature set
  • BBB: is stored best evaluation metric value
  • YYY: the selected feature set at each iteration
  • MMM: The evaluation metric, e.g. Entropy; Classification rate; Regression error
  • Recursive feature elimination method is similar: starts with the full set and eliminate one at a time.

LASSO (Embedded Method)

  • LASSO (least absolute shrinkage and selection operator)

  • Add a L1 regularisation term to reduce the number of effective features

  • The loss function is not differentiable. Sub-gradient methods or least-angle
    regression can be used to optimise the loss

  • A higher 𝜆 will make some of the weights of x becomes 0, hence reduce the dimensionalities.

Filter Method

  • Univariant feature selection (assuming features are independent to each other)

Popular Dimensionality Reduction Methods

Principal Component Analysis

PCA: Unsupervised

Two methods resulted the same PCA calculation.

  • Maximum variance
  • Minimise average projection error

PCA requires calculation of:

  • Mean of observed variables
  • Covariance of observed variables
  • Eigenvalue/eigenvector computation of covariance matrix

Linear Discriminant Analysis

LDA: Supervised

  • LDA is a predictive modelling algorithm for multi-class classification

  • Dimensionality reduction by providing a projection of a training dataset that best separates the examples by their assigned class

Manifold Learning

  • Manifold learning aims to learn the latent representation of the original data in lower dimensions.

  • PCA is a linear manifold learning method, which doesn’t work in some cases

Supervised Linear Models

Supervised vs Unsupervised

  • Both require a training dataset.
  • Supervised learning requires labels y for each instance.
  • Unsupervised learning does not use labels

Linear Model vs Nonlinear Model

Linear algorithms assume that the sample features x and the label output y are linearly related

  • Linear regression
  • Logistic regression (classification)
  • Naïve Bayes
  • Support Vector Machines (SVM)

Nonlinear algorithms assume a nonlinear relationship between x and y.

  • K nearest neighbour
  • Kernel SVM
  • Decision Trees
  • Neural Networks

Linearly Separable Definition

  • Datasets whose classes can be separated by linear decision surfaces
    • 100% classification accuracy in the training set
  • Implies no class-overlap
  • Classes can be divided by lines for 2D data or planes in 3D data

Parametric vs Non-Parametric Algorithms

  • Parametric algorithm (model-driven): assumes the data follows a specific distribution in its feature space or a pre-defined relationship between feature and outcome.
    • Linear regression
    • Gaussian naïve Bayes
    • Maximum likelihood classifier
  • Non-parametric algorithm (data-driven): approaches are not constrained to prior assumptions on the data distribution.
    • Decision trees
    • Neural networks

Classification vs Regression

  • Regression(predicting numerical values): estimate values for a given data.
  • Classification(predicting categorical values): assign class labels to data.

Overfitting vs Underfitting

  • Overfitting:
    • a model learns to map the training data too well, which negatively impacts the performance of the model on new, unknown, data.
    • Poor generalisability
  • Underfitting:
    • if it neither can model the training nor the test data correctly. Underfitting is easy to detect in the training phase using evaluation metrics.
    • Poor performance

Variance and Bias

  • Bias indicates the error between the approximated model to the ideal model.
  • Variance is the amount that the estimate of the target function will change given different training data.

Intrinsic Parameters vs Hyperparameters

  • Intrinsic parameters
    • Can be efficiently learned on the training set
    • Large in number
    • e.g. weights in linear regression or Artificial Neural Network (ANN)
  • Hyper-parameters
    • Must be learned by establishing generalisation error
    • No efficient search possible
    • Smaller in number
    • e.g. the number of nodes in an ANN or the weights of two terms in a loss function

Linear Regression

Univariate Linear Regression

Naïve Bayes

Based on Bayes’ theorem: P(A∣B)=P(B∣A)⋅P(A)P(B)P(A|B)=\frac{P(B|A)\cdot P(A)}{P(B)}P(A∣B)=P(B)P(B∣A)⋅P(A)​

  • Find the probability of A happening, given that B has occurred.
  • Assumption is that features are independent with the same importance (Naïve).
  • Naïve Bayes leads to a linear decision boundary
  • Multinomial Naïve Bayes
    • features are counts: number of occurrence
  • Gaussian Naïve Bayes
    • features are continuous values
  • Bernoulli Naïve Bayes
    • features are only binary values: yes or no

Supervised Nonlinear Models (1)

K Nearest Neighbour (KNN)

  • Input:
    • the training set TTT, category label set CCC and test object xxx.
    • Each object has features x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​.
    • The number of neighbours KKK.
  • Output: the category cxc_xcx​ of the test object xxx (cxc_xcx​ belongs to CCC)

Questions: KNN

Q2: How to determine K?
  • Cross-validation: Test different values of K and choose the one that minimizes the validation error.
  • Odd numbers are preferred in binary classification to avoid ties.
  • Smaller K: More sensitive to noise (high variance).
  • Larger K: Smoother decision boundaries (low variance, possible high bias).
Q3: What happens if K is an even number and there is a tie?
  • In case of a tie (equal votes for multiple classes), the algorithm can:
    • Choose randomly between tied classes.
    • Use secondary criteria, such as the class of the closest neighbor.
Q5: What are the advantages and disadvantages of KNN?

Advantages:

  • Simple and intuitive.
  • No training phase.
  • Works well for small datasets with well-separated classes.

Disadvantages:

  • Computationally expensive during prediction (due to distance calculations).
  • Sensitive to irrelevant or unscaled features.
  • Performance heavily depends on the choice of K and distance metric.

Hard Margin Support Vector Machines

Hard margin SVM is a linear model: line in 2D, hyperplane in higher D

Kernel SVM

Kernel SVM maps the original feature into a higher dimensional feature space

  • Use linear SVM to classify in the higher dimensional space

  • Use kernel trick to reduce the computational load

SVM Questions

Q1: What are the hyperparameters for soft SVM?
  • CCC: Controls the trade-off between maximizing the margin and minimizing the classification error.
    • Higher CCC: Less tolerance for classification errors (smaller margin).
    • Lower CCC: Allows more errors (larger margin).
Q2: What are the hyperparameters for kernel SVM?
  1. CCC: Same as soft SVM, controlling the margin vs. error trade-off.
  2. Kernel-specific parameters:
    • For RBF kernel:
      • γγγ: Controls the influence of individual data points.
        • Higher γγγ: Focuses on closer data points (complex decision boundary).
        • Lower γγγ: Considers farther points (simpler decision boundary).
    • For polynomial kernel:
      • Degree (ddd): The degree of the polynomial.
      • Coefficients (rrr): Offset in the polynomial equation.
Q3: How to use SVM to solve multi-class classification?

  • One-vs-One (OvO):

    • Pairwise classification between every two classes.
    • For NNN classes, train N(N−1)2\frac{N(N-1)}{2}2N(N−1)​ classifiers.
    • Final prediction is based on majority voting.

  • One-vs-Rest (OvR):

    • Train NNN classifiers, each separating one class from all others.
    • Final prediction is the class with the highest confidence score.

Supervised Nonlinear Models (2)

Decision Trees

Learn a “tree-like” representation of a training dataset to achieve classification/ regression of unseen data.

  • Decision node contains conditions to split the data
  • Leave node contains the group of data and the associated label that share similar characteristics

Binary Decision Trees for Classification

  1. Begin the tree with the root node ®, which contains the complete dataset.
  2. Find the best feature (attribute) using Attribute Selection Measure (ASM) to form a decision node
  3. Divide R into subsets using the best feature and best condition (e.g. threshold).
  4. For each subset find the best feature using ASM to split the data again
  5. Repeat steps 2-4 until the stopping condition is satisfied
    • all data in the branch belong to the same class
    • value difference in each leaf node is small enough

Best Feature and Condition at Each Decision Node

  • Greedy Search at each decision node

    • e.g. Age feature from 10 to 100, calculate ASM using (10.5,11.5, …, 99.5)

  • Attribute Selection Measure:

    • Entropy: measures uncertainty/purity of data SSS that contains CCC classes.

    • Information Gain: measures the difference in entropy before and after splitting data SSS using feature AAA.

Pros and Cons of Decision Trees

Pros:

  • Robust to features with different scales (don’t need feature normalisation)

  • Embedded feature selection (redundant features won’t be selected at decision node)

  • Scalable to handle a large training dataset

  • Could handle missing feature value by ignoring it

  • High interpretability

Cons:

  • Greedy search at decision node which is computationally expensive
  • Overfitting as the tree goes deeper (biggest problem)

Tree Pruning to Avoid Over-fitting

Use a validation set to calculate error (classification/regression) for different versions of pruned trees

Random Forest

Decision is made based on the aggregation of different variety of trees

  • N samples (e.g. 1000), F features (e.g.100), B trees (e.g. 500 trees):

    • Final decision is based on majority voting from B decisions.
    • Regression is based on average of B trees.
    • Uncertainty can be obtained based on ratios of positive/negative votes from B trees.

  • Bagging: the ensemble learning method that is commonly used to reduce variance within a noisy dataset.

    • For each of B trees, use randomly sampled 80% data for training and 20% for validation

  • Random Subspaces: randomly sampling the features (only use a random subset of features for each tree)

    • Don’t always rely on the same set of features.
    • To avoid certain features overly emphasised.
    • Classification uses F\sqrt FF​ features , Regression uses F/3F/3F/3 features.

Feature Importance in Random Forests

Permutation Importance or Mean Decrease in Accuracy (MDA):

  • Randomly permute feature values of the validation samples, and the accuracy is computed each time.
  • The decrease in accuracy as a result of this permuting is averaged over all trees.
  • The larger the decrease in accuracy the more important one feature is.

Neural Unit

Neural Network

  • Input layer connects to the input data (normally features)
  • Hidden layer performs feature interactions (weighted sum)
  • Output layer is in charge of the decision making

Activation Functions

Each neurons in the hidden layer and output layer contains an activation function.

  • Output layer’s activation function is task dependent

ANN Training

  • Randomly initialise the weights and bias: W and b
  • Input a data (normally a batch of data one by one) and perform forward passing, then generate a prediction.
  • Calculate the error between the predicted output and the true label.
  • Backpropagate the error from the output layer back to the input layer by calculating the averaged gradients of the batch for each W and b.
  • Update all W and b using the gradient (Gradient Descent).
  • Repeat 2-5, until the predicted output is good enough or W and b can’t be further updated.

Practical Issues

Data

Machine Learning algorithms are data-driven

Issue Description Impact
Noisy Data Poor repeatability/reliability, contains redundant information Decreases model performance
Incorrect Data Wrong labels or incomplete labels Misleads the model during training
Small Data Insufficient sample size Overfitting and overly optimistic results

Difference of Training, Validation and Test Sets

  • Training set

    • run the ML algorithm on.

  • Validation set

    • tune parameters, select features, and make other decisions regarding the learning algorithm.

  • Test set

    • evaluate the performance of the algorithm.

  • Don’t simply use random 70%/10%/20% split or cross validation

    • They does not guarantee that the validation and test sets reflect future data distributions
    • May result in over- or under-estimation of model performance on the test set

  • Validation set needs to be large enough to detect the performance difference, but not necessarily much larger

  • Test set needs to be large enough to provide a confident estimate

Error Mitigation

  • Bias Error: Model underfitting, fails to learn data patterns
    • Improve feature engineering (e.g. outlier removal)
    • Improve model architecture or try a better method
    • Reduce regularisation
    • Increase model size
  • Variance Error: Model overfitting, relies too much on training data
    • Add regularisation or decrease model size
    • Improve feature selection (reduce dimension, pick a subset)
    • Add more training data
  • Mismatch Error: Training and test data distributions are different
    • Understand the difference between training and test sets
    • Add more training data that are similar to the test cases

Analyse the Source of Error before Improving the Method

  • Your algorithm must perform well on the training set before you can expect it to perform well on the validation and test sets

  • Manually examine a subset of training set. Correct the labels or exclude the examples that are wrongly labelled, if necessary

  • Manually examine a subset of validation set manually, check the wrong cases and identify the problem that potentially makes the biggest improvement

Large Data set

  • If luckily you have a large dataset.

    • Don’t use them all at once.
    • As soon as you used the test set to improve your model, it is no longer a valid test set.

  • Divide the test set and validation set:

    • Test Set: Fully retained for final evaluation.
    • Validation Set: Split into Eyeball Set (manual analysis) and Blackbox Set (quantitative analysis).

  • Avoid overfitting:

    • When the Eyeball Set is used frequently to improve the model, a new Eyeball Set should be drawn from the Blackbox Set.

  • Size of Eyeball Set:

    • The lower the error rate, the larger the Eyeball Set needed to collect enough error samples.

Deep Convolutional Neural Networks-Applications

Overfitting is a big problem in deep learning

Problem:

  • Alexnet has 60 million parameters
  • VGG16 has a total of 138 million parameters
  • Resnet101 has 44.5 million parameters

Method to reduce overfitting:

Data Augmentation

  • Data augmentation increases the number of training samples by varying the original image’s geometry and appearance.
  • Data augmentation is normally performed during training not beforehand

Drop out

  • Randomly disable certain neurons during training.
  • Normally in fully connected layer, e.g. 20% dropout rate

Transfer learning

  • Train the Deep CNN using a large dataset (e.g. imageNet).

  • Then freeze the parameters of the first few layers, only retrain (fine tune) the high level feature layers or fully connected layers for a new application with small number of training samples.

Restrictions using transfer learning

  • Domain Gap:

    • If the pre-training dataset and the target dataset differ significantly, the migration may be less effective

    • ImageNet is a nature image while the target is a medical image

  • Choice of Freezing Layers:

    • Freezing too many layers may limit the model’s ability to adapt to new tasks;

    • Freezing too few can lead to overfitting and high computational costs.

  • Task complexity:

    • If the target task is very complex, more fine-tuning or even retraining may be required
    • new types of features need to be learnt

Generative Models

Variational Autoencoders (VAEs)

  • VAE is an encoder-decoder structure, constructed by neural networks.
  • It learns to reduce the dimensionality of the input data
  • The learned latent space (z) from encoder needs to be regularised, so that new examples can be generated by the learned decoder.

Regularisation

  • Without regularisation, the encoder-decoder model can be overfitted to the input data

    • Encoder may map the input data to isolated points (discontinuous space)
    • Decoder can only reconstruct training data well and cannot generate realistic new examples

  • In VAE, the encoder learns to map the input data into a normal distribution

  • So that we can then sample from this normal distribution to generate new examples using the decoder

Loss Function in VAE

  • Reconstruction term: makes the generated output as similar as to the input.
  • Regularisation term: makes the learned latent features from the encoder as close as to a Gaussian distribution

There is a trade-off between the regularisation and reconstruction loss.

  • Larger regularisation makes the reconstruction error larger, hence reconstructed data is less realistic
    • e.g. image blurry

Advantages and Disadvantages

  • Advantages:
    • Learned latent space is well constrained and easy to sample from.
    • Easier to train compared to other generative models: smaller training set.
    • Broad application scenarios: e.g. anomaly detection, data synthesis, etc.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Generated images tend to be blurry

Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)

GAN has two parts:

  • Generator: learns to generate plausible instances that looks realistic (i.e. synthesise data).
  • Discriminator: learns to distinguish the generator’s fake data from real data, which penalises the generator for producing unreal examples.
  • Both Generator and Discriminator are neural networks, which are trained iteratively

Discriminator

The discriminator is simply a classifier, which could use any network architecture appropriate to the type of data it’s classifying (e.g. VGG)

  • Real data: from real samples in the training set
  • Fake data: synthesised data from the generator

During discriminator training:

  • The discriminator classifies both real data and fake data.
  • The discriminator loss penalises the discriminator for misclassifying a real and a fake instance.
  • The discriminator updates its weights through backpropagation from the discriminator loss

Generator

The generator part of a GAN learns to create fake data by incorporating feedback from the discriminator.

It learns to make the discriminator classify its output as real

During generator training:

  • Input random noise (e.g. vector in a small dimension sampled from uniform distribution)
  • The input goes through the generator network to generate a data instance
  • The discriminator classifies the generated data with an output
  • Calculate the loss from discriminator classification, which penalises the generator for failing to fool the discriminator based on the output
  • Backpropagate through both the discriminator and generator to obtain gradients
  • Use gradients to change only the generator weights but don’t update the discriminator

GAN’s iterative training process

  • The discriminator trains for one or more epochs.
  • The generator trains for one or more epochs.
  • Alternate the above two steps to continue to train the generator and discriminator networks.
  • The generator improves with training and the discriminator performance gets worse. If the generator succeeds perfectly, then the discriminator has a 50% accuracy.
  • The discriminator feedback gets less meaningful over time makes GAN training unstable

Problems of GAN

  • Tough to train:
    • If the discriminator behaves badly, the generator does not have accurate feedback and the loss function cannot represent the reality.
    • If the discriminator does a great job, the gradient of the loss function drops down to close to zero and the learning becomes super slow or even jammed.
  • Mode Collapse:
    • During the training, the generator may collapse to a setting where it always produces similar outputs with low variety.
  • Tricks to improve GAN:
    • Use Wasserstein distance to replace KL divergence: discriminator no longer discriminate between real and fake but calculate a smooth distance of their probability distribution

Reinforcement Learning

RL trains an agent to take actions in an environment by sending reward and state

  • Employs trial and error to find a solution
  • Make a sequence of decisions
  • Do not require labelled input/output pairs but rules of reward and penalty.
  • Aim to take actions by maximising reward

Key Elements of RL

Term Description
Environment Physical world in which the agent operates
Agent Learn to act that maximises cumulative reward
State Current situation of the agent
Reward Feedback from the environment
Policy Method to map agent’s state to actions
Value Future reward that an agent would receive by taking an action in a particular state

Q-Learning

  • Q-learning is a method to find the next best action (aaa) given a current state (sss), Q(s,a)Q(s,a)Q(s,a) that aims to maximise cumulative reward.
  • Q value defines the quality of State/Action pair
  • Bellman Equation: determine the value of a particular state and deduce how good it is to be in that state.

Q-Learning Process

  • Initialise Q-values in a Q-table (e.g. 0s)
  • Choose an action a for state s (best Q-value)
  • Perform action a, results in a new state s’
  • Measure reward R
  • Update Q with Bellman Equation

Drawback: computationally expensive in both training and inference

Exploration vs Exploitation

  • Agent don’t normally know the environment.
    • Introduce some randomness on selecting actions
  • Epsilon-Greedy Exploration Strategy
    • At every time step when it’s time to choose an action, roll a dice
    • If it has a probability less than epsilon, choose a random action
    • Otherwise take the best-known action at the agent’s current state

Deep Q-Learning (DQN)

DQN: a neural network maps input states to action/Q-value pair

  • Initialise Q-values (network)
  • Network predict an action aaa for state sss
  • Perform action aaa, results in a new state s’s’s’
  • Measure reward RRR
  • Update weights of Neural Network using the Bellman Equation: R(s,a)+γmaxQ′(s′,a′)R(s,a)+\gamma_{max}Q'(s',a')R(s,a)+γmax​Q′(s′,a′).

Policy Gradients (PG)

  • PG uses a policy network to directly estimate actions rather than quality values
  • Input states (image, coordinates), output actions

Training Policy Network

  • Initialise the network with random weights
  • Forward passing the network to generate a possible action
  • With this action, keep executing the game until end (e.g. game over).
    • For a positive reward, encourage the selected action by backpropagating a positive gradient
    • For a negative reward, discourage the selected action by backpropagating a negative gradient
  • Play N episodes (e.g. rounds of games), updates the weights based on positive/negative gradients.

Summary and Challenges in Using RL

  • Model free method is the way forward and more flexible in dealing with unknown environment but slow to train.
  • Policy gradients normally performed better than deep Q learning.
  • Requires a large data to train, as no direct controlling of the agent but only through rewarding.
  • Reaching a local optimum: performing not as expected but the agent thinks it’s doing well.
  • The agent finds a shortcut in getting the rewards without completing the designed task.

Transformers

  • LSTM is able to capture long term memory but not long enough.
  • Transformers is able to capture dependencies between each input words and between all input words to outputs in a sentence.

Overview of Transformers

  • Encoder-decoder architecture
  • The Encoder output is a continues vector representation of the inputs
  • The Decoder takes this continues vector representation to generate output one by one.
  • Applications: language translation, chatbot, etc.
  • Transformers has been used everywhere (e.g. object classification, image segmentation, etc. )

Input Embedding

  • Each word is mapped to a vector
  • Add a positional encoding to the vector using sine/cosine functions

Encoder Training

  • The multi-head attention calculates the relationships between all pairwise inputs

  • The feed forward network (MLP) maps the attention vectors to something can be feed to the Transformer decoder.

Multi-Head Attention

  • Input, each word has Query, Key and Value

  • Scaled Dot-Product Attention->Scale->Softmax

  • For each input (e.g. word) compute multiple attention vectors (learnable weights WVW_VWV​, WkW_kWk​, WQW_QWQ​) and use the weighted (WzW_zWz​) average as the final attention vector for each word

  • Output vector © is the dot product between attention weight and value.

    • Multiple words are processed in parallel.

Decoder Training

  • the target sentence is input to the Masked Multi-head attention, Masked out relationships to future words

  • Then another Multi-head attention that learns the interactions between input words and target words (key and value are from the encoder, query is from decoder)

  • The output is one-hot encoding

Model Inference

  • The input sentence is input to the encoder to generate feature vector representation and feed to the decoder
  • A “start” input signal is input to the decoder
  • The decoder generate the first possible word in the target sentence.
  • This estimated word is then input the decoder to estimate the next word and iterate until an “end” signal.
  • To estimate the second words onwards the model uses the whole input sentence and all previously generated target words

Chat GPT

Three main steps in training Chat GPT

  1. Generative pre-training.

    • Solution: Transformer trained on large number of texts.

    • Problem: Generated texts do not necessarily answer the question (prompt).

  2. Supervised fine-tuning.

  • Solution: Human trainers to respond to prompt that are used as the label.
  • Problem: Machine responses are not matched exactly to human’s response with some false/forbidden/non-sense statements.
  1. Reinforcement learning from human feedback.
  • Solution: human trainers rank the responses and form a reward function to make machine behave. (proximal policy optimisation).

Trends & Challenges in Machine Learning

Diffusion Models

Aim: Noise to Image generation

Drawback:

  • Lack details for high-resolution images.
  • Computationally expensive.
